If you want to know if this game is fun and worth the money, the answer is: yes, absolutely, every time. The game play is inventive, the ghosts are varied, the locations are creepy, and every mission I play somehow feels new. But this game has something beyond the well-conceived mechanics and thoughtful design. There is something really magical here.

I play this game almost exclusively with my best friend, who lives across the country. There are not many things we can do together at this point in our lives, and time we have available seems to get more limited every year. Mostly, when we are able to hang out, we choose to hang out in Phasmaphobia. We know it will always be a good time. This game has proven, again and again, to be an endless well of hilarious jokes and creative inspirations. There is nothing quite like being terrified, locked in a bathroom, while a demon grumbles right outside the door, then watching your friend slowly inch toward the toilet while you beg him not to flush it. 

He will flush it. He will always flush it. 

And then you will die, and it will be the most fun you've ever had - until the next round, when you rejoice because you found a ouija board, and the ghost keeps telling you it is close and harboring a violent hatred, but you don't care because you just want to know whether or not this vengeful wraith likes jazz.

I've played this game for 71 hours. I am basically no better at it than when I started, and I hope never to improve. It's a joy. I could play it forever as a blissful idiot. I wish that for you as well. Buy it. Share the experience with someone you love.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

[h1]100/100 If you need a game that emulates how scary ghost hunting could be if the ghost was murderous, this is the game for you.[/h1]
[u]It's recommended you play with friends as this is a great coop experience.[/u]

- No jumpscares, but genuine fear invoking gameplay through ambient sounds, ghost activity such as laughter, rocking chairs, turning off lights, etc. Even when they kill you, it's uncanny and creepy, rather than cheep and ear piercing.
There are loud voices that can be heard, but the devs did a good job using these sounds sparingly or reasonably; spirit box speaker via communication with the entity, some spirits/ghosts will make noises even without a spirit box

- Suspense like no other horror game I've played yet, when hunt mode begins, my fight or flight senses kick in, and I try to find the best hiding spots in a horribly lit building (imagine how well that goes)

- Use of supposedly real spirits and ghosts from Banshee, Jinn, Oni, etc. With (over 15 spirits) each having minor differences of behaviour or evidence, some make the room cold, some turn off the power, some don't become active unless there is/isn't any hunters around.

Not what it was. Phasmophobia had a methodic atmospheric experience it could have harnessed to make the game even more unique but now it's most of an fps/throwing items simulator. Repeat. The same cycle was in the early game but it was less convoluted which is better and for that price at that time, a good game. Wow. This game is amazing! You may be scared or think you will never get better at the start, but the game just gets better as you do! You may also think that with randomly generated games that you will get games that are the same or boring. Well let me tell you something. Every game is unique! Sure I have gotten the same ghost before or the same cursed possession before but ever game is different. With a lot of different ghosts, 6 cursed possessions, and a TON of different maps ranging from street house to prison, this game has something for everyone! Want to sit in the van and let your friends die? You can! Want a more hands on approach with killing your friends? (I recommend music box!) You can do that too! There are endless ways to play every game. Endless challenges you can do! The small team of devs work so hard to fix all of the bugs in this game. (I don't thing I have ever seen a bug unless I was looking for it) They are also CONSTANTLY working on new updates like new ghosts, new maps, or new features! This game is flat out amazing! You might be frustrated at the start from the ghost killing you, but once you get past that the game is so much fun! There are a ton of different items to use for finding the ghost! Like thermometer, peramic, emf, video cam. This game is a ton of fun and the devs work hard to make it that way. I totally recommend this game!

Ghosts aren't following their own rules anymore.

Several times I've encountered scenarios where: I've smudged a spirit mid-hunt for it to just walk through said smudge and kill me anyways before the 6 second grace period is up, a Yurei has walked/is walking through solid walls and doors, Wraiths leaving footprint trails. None of it makes sense, none of it lines up with the very in-game journal they tell you to abide by. I've watched a Revenant full-tilt sprint at it's target who was hiding with no tech on in a closed room on the other side of the map (new hiding spot too), and no, their in-game voice was *not* active. I've seen Spirits act like Jinn (speeding up when far away, slowing down close, only worked when power was on), and almost every mimic I've seen hasn't actually mimic'd anything, not even the "Ghost orbs" mentioned in it's weakness have ever been there.

60% of the time an evidence bugs out and doesn't get triggered for ages (if at all).

All of this was encountered while playing with friends, or in solo-play, I don't play with randoms, so nobody was "controlling" the ghost either, before somebody decides to try and claim "just hackers" or anything.

Will amend my review when they update it so a single evidence no longer takes 30+ minutes of inactivity to finally trigger, and when ghosts actually follow their own rules from the journal.

Amazing game. Every game is full of action and has so much to offer, and is 200x better when playing with friends and messing around. Really hope this game is going to be relevant for at least a next couple years.
                                                                                                                                 
        I vividly remember loading into the first games, the first one being Bleasdale Farmhouse, the dreaded OG medium-sized map. 2 of my friends and I were strolling around the house, all bunched together, shitting our pants. We were just walking around with the normal flashlights, and exploring the area and with our items, trying to figure out how to use them. Everything was a mystery, and I had the dumbest theory that the lower the number on the spirit box got, the closer to the ghost we got. Looking back, even though the game is still very much exciting, nothing will top that adrenaline and passion for the game. Not sure exactly what happened after that, I think we just died off one by one until the ghost snapped all of our necks, or one of us died and the other two pussied out and just left in the truck. I just remember what happened during the start and middle of the game. 

        The second (I think it was second, or it was one of our first games when we all bought it) game was also wild. A mission at Willow Street House, and we were still trying to find out how to work the items we were given and how to successfully beat a mission without getting picked off by the ghost. When we got in, both my friends had the GREAT idea of making me sit at the end of the hallway right in between the master bedroom and the boy's bedroom in complete darkness, while they just stared at me through the doors in the living room, seeing if something happened. Of course my bot self agreed to it eventually after being skeptical about it when they first proposed the plan, so I just sat there, doing absolutely nothing but staring into the long dark hallway, waiting for the ghost to do something, whether it be killing me or doing something that could somehow give away the ghost type. As much as I don't want to admit it, I was actually scared for my life. I wanted to just dip and run back into the truck, and I had my headphones off maybe about 75% of the time, scared of what was to happen to me or what scary audio was awaiting me as time went on in the pitch black willow home. At maybe around 10 minutes of me being there, the ghost initiated a hunt from god knows where and murdered me, helpless as my teammates just watched it all unravel in front of their eyes, watching me choke to death and fall face down in front of the little drawer with my legs twisted in 4 different ways. You know, maybe if we knew what smudge sticks and lighters were (actually it doesn't even matter because I don't think we even had them unlocked LMAO) I could have lived that hunt, or if I just had actual braincells, but too bad. Although it was undeniably scary, we all had a blast and I'll never forget what happened that night. 

        For sure worth the 12 dollars.

If You Like Ghost Hunting Games I Will Recommend this game it's super fun to play with friends

Phasmophobia was the first game I bought and installed when I purchased my gaming PC. I put a lot of hours into this game when I initially started playing. It is a ghost hunting game and if you have a few friends to play with I will most definitely say you'll get your money's worth. 

Pros: You can play with up to three friends, there are several different maps to choose from, several different ghosts, the game is constantly being improved to make it more challenging (ghosts that are harder to detect,) and depending on your own personal threshold you can prepare for jump scares.

Cons: Over time the scare wears off- especially once you've put almost 200 hours into the game, it can be a bit buggy at times, and it does tend to get repetitive once you've played for so long.
Really fun and scary to play with your friends. Public lobbies aren't nearly as good tho

Extremely well designed game. From mechanics, to atmosphere, to graphics. The game boasts it all. I continue to play Phasmophobia repeatedly due to its unique gameplay characteristics, thrilling atmosphere and visual fidelity. The game creates a chilling atmosphere that other games just don't manage to do as effectively. There is never a point where I don't feel uneasy when roaming the halls of a haunted location. I like how the game manages to create scares with out doing too much, It is extremely different to most horror titles I've played and subverts typical horror stereotypes seen in most other horror games creating a unique playing experience that is not for the fainthearted. The game also boasts unique mechanics such as being able to talk to the threat and further more being able to anger the threat with what you say to it. This feature is unlike anything I've seen before and it is extremely well executed and at least in my experience, it has no noticeable flaws.
Besides the gameplay aspects, the games graphics are also something to note. While the graphics are extremely simple, it manages to maintain a great graphical style which always provides a pleasant viewing experience. The use of reflections is also well implemented adding a touch more of realism to the game while not being too overbearing.
Overall this game is fantastic. Every aspect of the game is well thought out and provides a satisfying and addictive experience that keeps you coming back for more. I highly recommend it!

The OG ghost hunting game. As a mainly solo player, it's not my personal favorite gh game, but it's certainly the most polished. Very atmospheric and well made. Even when playing other gh games there are things I wish were more like phasmo, like the smoothness of opening doors, emf readers actually responding to everything, and the perfect feeling of progression in each hunt. It may be a simple "Phase 1 gh game" where you only play ghost detective to identify the ghost type, but it's very good at being just that. Needs more jump scares, though.

Using the equipment to find the ghost is pretty easy after a few playthroughs. But I have played this game for about 100 hours now and it still scares the crap out of me. Even going in fully aware of everything and whats about to happen, it's hard for me to play this alone.

I've been playing strictly with one friend. We were both scared at first and barely made any progress (we also skipped the tutorial :P). As we got used to how the game works, we got less and less scared and started having many successful missions. I wouldn't play this game without at least one friend.

You would think the game gets really boring after you've seen everything but it's actually fun to figure out the ghost type once you have experience.

At this point, I am not sure for how long the game will entertain me but there is decent replayability and it's still early access so I expect it to get a lot more content considering its success.

TL;DR
Better with friends, good replayability, fun to play a couple of missions here and there.

Pros:
* Can play solo or with up to 3 others
* Easy to learn mechanics with time
* Walkie-Talkie voice chat system makes for some interesting games
* If you die you can walk around and move stuff/potentially help out your team which is either helpful or hilarious
* Randomized ghosts and evidence keep replayability very high!
* Multiple Locations to Ghost hunt at
* 24 Ghost types to encounter (as of 8/11/22)
Cons:
* Hiding spots can sometimes make parts of your character stick out resulting in a death
* Ghosts sometimes aren't active enough resulting in a lackluster time

All in all the negatives are minor inconveniences at most. Phasmophobia (or Phasmo as most players call it) is a great game all about hunting ghosts with your friends or other players. I recommend it to anyone who likes horror games!

Love the game really good, fun and would recommend picking it up if you want something close to those videos on Telly where they sit in a room and spend and hour trying to talk to something that isn't their, but with this game it is real.

(what I would like to see or mostly like to see once the game leaves EA)

Things I would like to see in this game further in development when it's finished.

-Better animations for the player's and ghosts. 

-Non Fuze Models for the characters and most likely characters made by the developers (Preferably with body slider and face slider and full customisation).

-Better sprint since you run out of breath in a second feeling so unfair and un-natural.

-More Ghosts designs (Preferably ones that show how the ghost died or can give a hint to what it can be, ghosts that fly like the wraith and banshee actually fly).

-better and smoother controls for Non VR players.

-A way to exercise the ghost.

-Players when dead can interact with more things as well as use the spirit box to talk to the living.

-More Items, maybe some that do the same thing but have it a different way (Like a Drone or RC car that has a camera on it but has a battery life as well as can be disabled or have it's battery drain faster by hosts that feed from electricity).

-Better rewording system since mostly now it's best to just play on nightmare and take pictures of the bones, Cursed Item and then other things like the take multiple pictures of the Quija board after you ask it's age for the 50th time.


(Reason for negative review)
Also just giving it a bad review because the developer made it harder to mod now and now it's hard to increase the server size, This game isn't competitive or anything and is just a fun game to play with friends but the fact they are trying to restrict modding and increasing the player count is why I am giving a bad review. Just let people do that stuff it only benefits the game. Won't change my review to positive until they make the change to make it more modifiable like it was before the recent update.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn.
Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

The game currently lacks majorly in UI / UX and is very very hard to learn the core mechanic if you don't look for external content

Pros:
 - Very fun to play with friends
 - Scary AF
 - Supports VR (I don't have one, but it's a cool idea for the game)

Cons:
 - Very very poor UI / UX
 - Game lacks on teaching new players and in tutorial content (e.g How the hunts work? What exactly are the main and other objectives of the game? What are the benefits of purcashing an specific item?)
 - Literally needed to watch youtube videos to properly understand the game mechanics
 - Most servers have at least 1 cheater that uses an ESP and/or infinite money (Can be a pro if u just want to collect money tbh)
 - Cant change game settings while in a multiplayer lobby

Overall it's a great game idea, but the devs should be careful whith the UX, making the game more user-friendly could provide new players a better experience instead of basically throwing them into the gaming and expect them to die because they will spend 10 minutes to figure out how to use Smudge Sticks

Very spooky. Lots of replayability due to the variety of ghosts and ghost behaviors. It's pretty fun figuring out the secret abilities of ghosts; this becomes necessary when you play on nightmare mode, where one piece of evidence is hidden from the hunters. Lots of stuff to learn and keep you occupied, with every hunt you take part in being a unique experience. There is still content and updates to come as well. Very fun with friends but playing solo is its own challenge and enjoyable as well. I love playing mostly solo now, but it can be pretty terrifying/daunting at first. Knowledge is power though, so it eventually becomes not as scary. There can still be those terrifying moments however, even after many hours of play.

The only problem I have had is trying to get games with randoms in public lobbies. If you are a low level, a lot of players will instantly kick you due to your inexperience, preventing you from learning anything. People will also kick you for seemingly no reason. To counteract this I recommend playing solo or with friends only on a low difficulty at first, and gradually build your way up. There is a lot to learn about this game, so a lot of players will get annoyed with you if you don't understand everything, which is pretty dumb.
A bit fuzzy and janky around the edges, but the core gameplay is a lot of fun especially with a team of friends. Played a lot in early access, hopefully going to get even better with more polish.

Other than that, I'd say that their efforts are otherwise paying off and that everyone who plays/played should appreciate them for making such an amazing game.

I got this game right around it's beginning release, since then I can definitely say that it has never gotten better, in fact it has only gotten significantly worse. Voice recognition seems to be worse off than it was before, often time not being able to understand what was said in any capacity other than registering words were indeed spoken. The cursed objects update introduced mostly nothing fresh to the gameplay, just more picture opportunities, a worse ouiji board, and useless objects that would never help in the hunt, at least play tarot card roulette is fun. The evidence is boring and repetitive, you'll see the same ghosts and evidence frequently because there isnt enough variety with the amount of evidence you can even collect so many of the ghosts just share 2/3 evidence. When you find the ghost there's nothing left to do and it doesn't feel fulfilling in any way, cool I found 3 pieces of boring evidence and know what the ghost is, time to do it again and have nothing be different. On bigger maps they look awful mostly just looking the exact same in every room, like they copy and pasted each room over and over again next to each other to increase size, most of the time on big maps you'll get stuck in a hunt loop where you finish a hunt, get close to the ghost room and then immediately be hunted again because they poorly designed every aspect of ghost hunts. The sound design is awful, you'll hear the same groan, crying or whisper ninety percent of the time, maybe just maybe you'll hear singing once in a blue moon but none of them, minus the later, actually sound good at all. Half of your evidence doesn't register itself properly because of terrible ghost ai which can be broken or cheesed even during hunts or they act so super-powered that from across the map they'll chase down your hiding spot to kill you because there's no balance. Not a single update has come to this game to give it more personality or flavour and almost always make the gameplay worse. This game spawned a ton of copycats and ironically almost all of them do it miles better because the devs for this game clearly don't give a fuck about making it fun, and they aren't good at adding anything useful. They just toss a new map that's just a recycled older map and then move on.

This game was really awesome, unfortunately now it's just getting worse and worse, with every update the game is getting further and further away from the fun game I know, long ago when I first started playing it in 2020 we played it with my friends every day, it was entertainment that managed to frighten, laugh, etc
I don't recommend this game at the moment, if I was giving a review in 2020 I might even say that it was one of the most fun online games I've ever played, it would be great if the developers made a version of the game that was the good old one, at that moment I think that it would also make a big boom in the internet world, by which I mean twitch, youtube, etc.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week, he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character, and started playing but I was stuck on what I was supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I am a 46-year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing Phasmophobia . I am a single father to my son, who is now 19. My son started playing Phasmophobia in 2017. In less than a month, he had already played for over 100 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son because he was always out with his friends or watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account to play with my son. I started playing, but this was my first time playing a video game since the 90's, so I was quite lost. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing Phasmophobia. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Incredible survival game but can be subjective based on who you play with. I highly suggest new players play solo if they dare, or try to find friends or other players who are also new. Many seasoned players, understandably, have many mechanics and strategies down second nature and it can take away a lot of the fun for new players. (I say this as a very seasoned player).

For example, a lot of people who’ve played a while have watched videos or just learned through experience how to solve the ghost puzzles through advanced means that really take away a lot of the danger and scare.

I implore any new players to just experience the game through trial and error. Done this way, this is one of the best value games I’ve ever purchased. 

Learn by trying and failing/succeeding. Watching too many videos or jumping in with experienced players can really alter the gameplay experience.

Use the few tools that the game gives you to start off with and do your best. You don’t have to figure out the ghost and solve every bonus objective to succeed. It’s better to survive and leave with what items and money you have earned than to try too hard and die, which sets you back on money and equipment.

TLDR: amazing game but it’s based on your gaming integrity. I still play this every now and then for hours of fun and scares.

Was bought this by a friend to play with them. Three games later, refunded so they could keep their money because i'm sure not touching it again.
The gameplay is extremely slow and unrewarding, it mostly focuses on menial tasks and trial and error. I assume it's intended that you're constantly on edge scared of the ghost - I was not, particularly, because there's not a great deal of atmosphere. I was just running through a dark house. When the ghost actually shows up it's very obvious what's going to happen - either you're totally out of position and die or you aren't, and live. 
The whole game looks awful - I can't hold this against the developers, I understand they're a small team. Having said that, when the game is billed to me as the scariest experience of the year and i'm being chased by what looks like a gmod npc moving at a slow pace, I really struggle to get engaged. I have played other small budget indie horrors that look way better and cultivate a way scarier atmosphere as a result.

I can see why some people like this game. If you scare easily, if you have a group of friends and are in it for the 'funny moments' vibe, this might be for you. For me, this was a dreadful experience, not scary in the slightest and also not particularly fun.

I need to get this message out before it is too late. Phasmophobia is a PC game gaining major traction, it is played by thousands, even the biggest Twitch streamers are starting to get involved with it. I was a part of the development team, specifically the team that came up with the concepts behind the ghost lore. The concept of the game is to walk around haunted locations and hunt ghosts using various equipment. The ghosts can hunt you back, it is actually quite an exciting game. Unfortunately, there have been unforeseen consequences with the game. When you play Phasmophobia, you are given a name, as well as clues to discover the type of ghost you are hunting. Once you discover the ghost type, you can use its name as well as its ghost type to generate a reaction out of it, make it angry, and get more money out of it. There was a concept that we never realized, that maybe calling out a dead person’s name, as well as the name of a malevolent entity could have dire consequences. They just might actually be listening; they might actually be hunting.

When you are sitting in the game with your headphones on, calling out to an unknown entity by name... you are not just calling out in game, you are also calling out in the real world. Recently, some of our team have felt like they are being watched, followed, and unsafe in their own homes. A picture knocked off the wall, doors open that were closed before, cupboards open in the kitchen. Initially, it was just enough to cause concern, make them lose a little sleep, keep them on edge. Their work started to falter, they were showing up late for shifts, and above all they were absolutely TERRIFIED to play Phasmophobia, a game they invented. On Monday morning, one of our gameplay testers, I will just be using his initials, KW, failed to show up altogether. He had never missed a day, not for any reason whatsoever. We decided to go to his apartment to check up on him. When we arrived the door was open, and KW's neck had been snapped. There didn't look to be any sort of struggle or forced entry. The police chalked it up to a fall, just a sad accident.

While we were cleaning out KW's apartment, we noticed certain irregularities. For one, KW purchased a Ouija board the same day he died. He also purchased a walkie talkie, an electronic thermometer, and a UV flashlight. All items we use in Phasmophobia for the user to track the ghost. KW had spent 30 hours playing Phasmophobia. 30 hours calling out to ghosts, entities. 30 hours calling out to evil.

Today, I finished my shift, and signed off at exactly 30 hours. Maybe KW did just fall, maybe there really is nothing suspicious about his death. But my apartment feels cold... and I think I left my bathroom door closed? I definitely turned off my kitchen sink before I left... Or did I? I think there must be an issue with my electricity, my lights keep flickering. Maybe I am just paranoid, or maybe something heard me repeatedly calling it out. Maybe our lore was too accurate, our information was too good, and we are actually calling out to the spirits beyond the grave.

I will be sleeping with my crucifix tonight. Based on our game... It will not be enough. If this post does not get updated, my worst fears were realized. The entities we have been calling out to have heard us, they have heard us taunting them, calling to them, and they are coming for us.

Fantastic experience. I can't remember ever being as genuinely terrified playing a game as I have been when playing this. It's an authentic-feeling, ghost-hunting experience, akin to the paranormal activity movies. Currently, it's also £10.99. For the price, it's such a bargain, but it really, really benefits from having friends to play with. I also think it would be exceptional to have a go at it in VR too. 

That being said, it's still early access, which means there are a few areas I'd like to see improvement in. Specifically, the multiplayer needs some changes. It could do with the ability to filter lobbies by language for a start. It would also be great to have a 'vote to kick' mechanism rather than just having the host able to kick. Quite often, when you join a public lobby, you'll be kicked by the host straight away if you're a low level, despite the fact that your level has virtually no impact on the playing of the game. This means you'll often spend quite a lot of time trying to join a game without getting kicked. When kicked, the game puts you back onto the main menu, which means navigating back through to the lobby menu every - single - time. Jarring. 

I'd also really like to see some depth added to the single player experience. At the moment, there is a single player mode, but it just isn't compelling at all. I think it would really benefit from having a 'campaign/story mode' added to it - gradually unlocking new missions, equipment, and locations - to make it a viable single player game. At the moment, it feels like it will live and die based on its multiplayer audience.

Overall great game, has a lot of potential and in my opinion there is not much of it that they wasted.
Sure, there are some imperfections here and there,
but since the game is only in the Version 0.6.3.1, I expect a lot more to be released before it leaves Early access.
It's a lot of fun in multiplayer with friends, but I didn't yet test out public rooms.
Anyways, here are some ideas and wishes for the game's future:

[h2] Character Customisation [/h2]

In the current state of the game, there is barely any. You have around 6 selectable characters (3 men and 3 women I think) and nothing else. 
Another problem is the leveling, since you get absolutely nothing for leveling beyond the highest shop requirements (About level 24-26 or so). 
A good way to tackle [b] both [/b] of these "problems" (It's not really a problem but rather concepts that aren't that ripe) would be an approach like leveling past Level 100 in Destiny 2.
In Destiny 2, you get a so called "bright engram" every 5 levels past the big 100. In these bright engrams you can find 2 possible things: An in-game currency called "bright dust" or cosmetics (like weapon skins, ship skins and emotes).
I think that getting a random reward every 5-10 levels would fit this game too! Now, I don't mean that we need to default dance on a demonic circle or something, I had things like in-game Money, Character customisation items (like a different jacket for character #5 or a mask for character 
#2) or simply investigation gear (like a parabolic microphone or a sound sensor) would be a good reason to make the level system feel more like something that actually rewards you and not just a number below your name on the whiteboard.

[h2] Equipment [/h2]

Stuff like traps where you can contain the ghost for a few seconds during a hunt (like a demonic circle but without the summoning part) would be an awesome addition for the game, and maybe (but I don't feel like that would really fit a game like this) adding a class to the different characters like it was done in the Chernobyl Liquidators game would be an idea to test for a short period of time and see if it qualifies as a good mechanic.

[h2] Miscellaneous [/h2]

Add EMF-5 to hunts from ghosts that have EMF-5 please.
Add a little map of the, well map where you play on into the journal, where you can mark different locations like the found bone or assumed ghost room on, but not see yourself or your teammates.

That's it. Now, you don't need to add these, it's just something thast I would really embrace to see in the future of this game, and I'm quite sure that I'm not alone on that
It's easier to play with friends (to get over the ambiance and the fear). But! It's rewarding and very much fun the more you get over the general fear.

[b]"A surprisingly challenging, unnerving and detailed game focused on detective work."[/b]

[i]Feet touch the walkway,
during the middle of the night.
A building covered by moonlight
entices footsteps close by.

Within its dark corridors,
Laughs heard, as if miles away.
Apparitions seen on cracked mirrors.
Outlet sparks, nearby a fallen toy.

Something is here.

Camera on the kitchen counter, 
observes an ominous mirror.
Within the garage a projector,
and salt spread on the floor.

The camera observes a figurine.
A reflection of what once was,
Cryed it did, it has been seen.
Ran it did, up the stairs.

Purple light clear the darkness
Shine on the door, for it moves
Reveal the unseen prints
Though its time to face the fears

Spirit box, let them speak
"Where are you?"
On the floor, a written book
"I'm with you."

Within the room, again, the toy
A case, yet, an untold story 
What was once a kid's joy
Became a nightmare, scary

It appears, allows to be seen
He holds the toy by the hand
The Generator broke down
eternal night claims the land

He cries alone, on the shadow room
There was no anger, gone long ago  
Yet, the misleading feel of doom
Teach us, nothing is greater than sorrow[/i]

A normal case solved by evidence
Yet, a detective's weapon
Always its own deduction
Dare to venture into this universe?

It is scary to walk in a pitch dark room with only a flash light in your hand while you try and find the light switch to turn on the light in that room, and also the fact that you know that the ghost entity will mess with the lights, so keep your flashlight handy at all times, its your best friend. You also have that gut feeling that someone or something is watching your every move as you hear the floor creaking and doors open for you to find. The objectives are sometimes challenging as well and it puts your mind and investigation skill to the test to find evidence that lead to what type of ghost your dealing with is.

Are your pants too clean? Do you feel like you don't have enough fecal matter in your undergarments? Want to constantly have clammy hands and a bad grip on your mouse due to palm sweat?

This is your game.

This game truly makes me feel SCARED. Between the dark environments, the silence of most areas, and the fact that you know something is in there with you, it all adds up to one of the scariest experiences you could imagine. Along with this, there are a bunch of cool items and features to mess around with, and in-game voice chat is really easy to use. Items are easy to collect, and finding evidence to prove what type of ghost you're dealing with is the perfect challenge. On top of all of this is the price. I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I loved this game when if first came out.  Even after some of the updates it was still really fun.  Now, it's just gotten ridiculously hard.  The game is no longer fun.  We had 3 of us playing yesterday (all veterans to the game) and 3 different sites we all died and that was on intermediate. I'm sure others like the extreme challenge, but intermediate should not be impossible to play for users who have been on the game since day one. One game we played we got zero clues and had been in the game for at least 20 to 30 minutes.  Of course we all died.  It's just becoming impossible to play since being able to advance depends on money which depends on being able to complete a quest.  I can't recommend this game anymore because of this.

Phasmophobia is a very intriguing game, that uses strategic tactics to make you use equipment to find ghosts. Phasmo can be a multi player game for up to 4 people. My friends and I love jumping on phas and joking around to pass some of our free time while hunting and determining the ghost. The developers are always coming out with re-vamps, that always bring a new aspect and excitement to the game.

This is the first game of its kind that I've purchased, there are A Lot out there that are very similar in concept and style. I picked this cause of the overwhelming positive reviews over the others. This game is far from a perfect title by any means, lighting needs to be worked out a little better, the game is frustratingly dark. I feel in time, with the Developers support fine tuning this game it'll get way better.  It's just not there yet, yes its fun, yes its atmospheric, I just feel there's so much that can be done to make it even better then it is. Luckily its in Early Access, so that is why I'm recommending this title. If it was finished as is, I'd probably skip on it after a demo, but its definitely worth the $13.99. I have no review of its VR capabilities.

Honestly, this is probably my favorite horror game ever. I've gotten to the point where I'm level 500, which is small compared to some other people's ridiculous levels. Firstly, the game looks and feels stunning (and this game is still in early access). The character models are a bit interesting, but this can lead to some very hilarious situations. In the current standings of the game, it is a bit hard for new players to get off the ground, but with a little determination, it can provide a challenge. The devs also put in a tutorial for new players, so you don't just get thrown into the mix with very little instructions. Each mission gives you a ghost with different abilities, interaction rates and aggressive behaviors. Each mission also provides the players with three different optional objectives for people to complete. These can include having the ghost walk through salt, stopping it from hunting with a crucifix, and many more. If the player manages to complete these objectives, they are rewarded with extra cash, which can be used to buy extra equipment for your next mission.  The game (as I'm writing this) has four difficulties to choose from, with custom difficulties on the way. The higher difficulty, the more money you get. You can play solo, or you can gather up to 3 friends to find the ghost together. If your feeling brave, you can also join random public lobbies, or set up your own. Suffice to say, this game is a must if you like co-op horror survival games. Hope you don't have Phasmophobia ;)

So I have no idea about this game but I have a rift S VR headset.
So I buy the game and install it and go right into it without any clue whatsoever.

First I land in the team room where everyone is amazed I have VR and can apparently move my arms.
Anyway, So my first level with this crew is that appartement. I go into the appartement with my team and I just walk around and enjoy the VR experience. Everyone is talking and I decide to walk into the basement. Suddenly no one is talking anymore and i hear steps. I walk upstairs and everyone is gone. I start feeling weird what is happening. I walk to the door but the door is closed. I dont understand what is happening. I scream why they closed the door and if they can hear me.
I hear footsteps behind me when a shadow or something is walking torwards me. 

This was honestly the worst horror experience of my life as a 37 year old gamer. I had no idea what is happening and it certainly peed myself a little. Its hard to describe but playing this game in VR and having no clue is a great experience.

Btw i actually survived. Whatever the thing was it walked in front of me but then it dissapeared and the door opened.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I love this game, BUT I recommend waiting for the game to fix a lot of things before buying if you have a computer that doesn't have a great track record of running beefy games. 

It has a little ways to go in terms of optimization. Watching youtubers and streamers with beefy computers play this game does not prepare you for the actual gameplay experience. Even with a good computer I hit a ton of lag spikes whenever the game is trying to load something. Rain cuts the FPS down to like 5. The campsite is so god awful. I cant open the tent doors without lagging the game to hell and it sucks because I love that map. Some of my friends have found the game borderline unplayable. 

A game like this should not run so badly even on the lowest settings. The game looks nice, don't get me wrong, but it doesn't look like it should be this resource intensive. The game is great, but it's badly optimized. If those problems were fixed (and if the tripod wasnt damn near impossible to pick up) I would completely recommend it. But until then, buy at your own risk.

Phasmophobia is a very good game, and it will always be scary to me. Overall it has a genuinely scary atmosphere despite it's common visual glitches. The sound design is also spectacular, combining the quiet eerie ambience and general lack of noise can make even the smallest of sounds terrifying. 

However I believe it could take some changes. First off, it would be nicer to have an expanded variety of maps, ghosts, evidence, and maybe different ways to die aside from choking to death. Also I think it'd be nice to see some more story in the game; so far it has only been "This person died and is now a ghost." Some indication of how they died would be cool to see, it wouldn't be too important, but maybe some sorta side-objective could be implemented with it. There should also be something to help players without microphones play the game, maybe a chat of some sort to communicate with their team and with the ghost. And finally, a versus mode would also be interesting, however it probably shouldn't have any rewards since those matches might probably be cheated in with friends. It should also probably be on a bigger scale of maps, so that the matches aren't just the ghost camping at the door and spamming hunts.

If you are looking for a great horror game that works with single-player and multiplayer, this is the game to get.

What a well thought out, and highly addictive game! I would gladly pay over 40 dollars for this game! I never was into the ghost hunting genre and, when I first saw the click bait youtubers pretend to freak out while playing, I thought it was going to be a colossal waste of time (what game would make anyone throw an expensive headset and and scream like they were actually being murdered?) ....until  I played it for the first time! Playing this game in the dark will freak you the efff out (not going to give spoilers here though). I don't know that I could play it in VR. I can not overstate how much I enjoy this game. The game mechanics are generally smooth. The "lore" does come from real world beliefs, and tools are what you would use in the real world. It is possible to get lucky in this game, but you do have to think your way through each map. No two hunts are the same. Even adding more players does not guarantee success, but it IS just as fun!
Developers are always adding Holiday themes and fun events. A lot of developer time goes into small details that just make the game special. Love the continuous updates! Tools are always changing to be as realistic as possible. developers are very open with future plans for the game  Not like other games that over promise and then get abandoned once the developers made the early access money.

I'd like to note first of all that all the negative reviews I've read thus far have been inaccurate. This game is amazing, although more of a game to play with friends or other people.
There are lots of bugs, unfortunately. None of the bugs I've seen are major, although if you plan on playing in VR, I've broken the game during VR sessions many times. It is super easy to clip through and inside things, or even fall through the floor if you're trying. I'm really disappointed with the VR experience, that being my only major gripe with the game. Everything else is awesome. Give yourself about 30hrs of experience and by then you should be decent enough at the game to join the public lobbies.
Unfortunately the community doesn't like playing with the newbies, which is understandable as the game takes a long time to learn and when newbies mess up (which is very often) then the people who bought all the in game equipment have to pay.
Those are my concerns. However despite them I love this game, the are trying really hard to update and add to the game, adding new features which add more depth or customization or a nice coat of polish to areas that were lacking. They seem to listen to the community and actively participate with streamers. A loving team who put their souls into this game. 
The game is always exciting to load up, me and my friends giggling over something stupid we did, like making fun of the ghost only to have it hunt us, or to have the door close on the last person and then they die. Just stupid funny things like that. I highly recommend picking this game up!

When you first start to play, don't try to be a hero. You will be absolutely terrified. Don't even bother trying to lie to yourself. We all know you're scared. Ghost events are horrifying, and the ideaof a ghost hunt fills you with dread.

Now once you've made it through your first few hundred levels, you can call yourself a veteran and will only let out a mild squeak during jumpscares without judgement. But you own the ghost now. The ghost checks its closet for you before going to sleep, so when you come through the door, it's frightened of you rather than the other way around.

pros 
-very fun to play with friends
-ghosts are unique beyond just their 3 points of evidence
-diverse maps that offer different challenges
-houses have enough furniture to seem realistic without being distracting
-sound effects are pretty great
-you can kill your friends with cursed possessions in the first 2 seconds of entering a house and then have them convinced it was an early hunter (epic)

cons
-laggy sometimes
-no way to join another lobby as a premade (you have to wait for people to join you which can take A WHILE)
-large maps can be boring if you get something like a shade

Came in expecting nothing more than every other horror game out there, jump scares, cheap tricks.

Phasmophbia, when played with friends is a tonne of fun, you begin to learn the patterns and tricks over a few hours and you begin to feel like proper ghost hunters. I'm sure at some point you "figure out" the AI and the magic wanes but until then, bring it on.

Does horror in that "it's not what you see" way, it's carefully crafted, but with enough abstraction to make a replay of a level interesting enough to try again.

I would say however that some of the levels, especially the larger ones are bland and empty, School seems to have this disjoint between the classrooms and the corridors, the quantity of rooms is excessive, it'd be just as good with half as many. Prison suffers this too. 

The smaller, more detailed levels are the most fun, content needs to keep coming though or the game will get stale, we need new voices, new behaviours, new ghost types, new maps to keep this fresh.

So for now it's on our regular cycle and getting a lot of laughs and scares, I would reccommend.

Let me preface that this game is in early access so you should expect some bugs here and there, not game breaking or anything.

The game at its core is really fun, it mixes the fear of unknown and the need of deduction to rule out ghosts (especially in Nightmare difficulty), but you will also have to take notes of strengths and weaknesses of the ghost you may be facing; on top of it, a lot of different ghosts make the game feel unique in any contract.

The maps are only a few so especially on the smaller roadhouses you may just get bored of the usual environment, but with some differences based on RNG (breaker position/hiding spots, cursed possessions and the ghost room) it really feels like a different game everytime.

Of course sometimes it may feel unfair with some combination, but with it being a PvE game you can quickly just get into the next match easily, also, farming money in this game is really easy, so unless you die really frequently you will be able to stock up some cash to buy the best equipment.

This game is also fairly scary, especially when playing by yourself, ghost events really set the tone and can catch you by surprise, or the sound of footsteps getting closer during a hunt can really be unsettling.

Overall my personal experience is pretty postive, and I'm looking forward for more content for this game (also personal reccomendation is to not play too much in a single burst to avoid burn out)

Phasmophobia still is the king for now (7/27/2022).  

Ghost Exile has some things above Phasmophobia, but this game is just smarter, I would say.

THATS ENOUGH OF MY COMPARISON><   now to review

Phasmophobia is clucking terrifying!!!  I have almost ruined like 7 or 8 pairs of underwear playing this game.  In between shidding your pants, you will find a detective type mystery game.  You are to determine what the ghost is!!! I mean, while you are literally freaking out and running and crying and wondering why the front door is now locked.

This is the penultimate ghost hunting game.  There is someting so eerie about exploring a vacant luminal space while you hear doors far away creaking open.  Ive set up a video camera and watched as a door slowly opened from the safety of the ghost busting RV.  

If you like horror.  This is your game.  If youve never tried horror... this is it.  This about as scary as it gets.

I could see why other people like this, but it's just not for me. It's very repetitive and I could never play for longer than half-an-hour as all missions just felt the same. The locations are decently diverse but they're all so dark and gloomy, it doesn't really make any difference. My biggest complaint, and this might make me sound childish, is that there's no way to defeat or incapacitate the spirits. If you enjoy the gameplay of identifying the type of spirit, good on you, but to me it's just going down a checklist with no climax. That said I have to applaud it for having a really good online community, I hardly ever encountered a troll when joining a random lobby and everyone was very polite in helping a noobie like me. Ultimately, you might still be able to get some enjoyment out of the atmosphere, and it's always worth giving the game a try, but if you share my sensibilities on other games, I don't think you'll like this one.

This game is super fun to play. While initially very scary, as you play more of the game you get hooked on the investigative aspect of the game. With plenty of different ghost types, each with their own quirks and special abilities, Phasmaphobia creates a learning curve for players to be able to figure out different ghosts not only from the evidences that they give, but also the characteristics of each ghost.

Pros:
-Horror game but still addictive for its investigator aspect
-Multiplayer allows you to investigate with your friends for hours of fun
-Moderate learning curve to learn the different maps each with their own spawns of the cursed items, as well as specific hiding spots to look for.
-Moderate learning curve to learn the different ghosts each with their own evidences, characteristics and special abilities
-You get to laugh at your friends dying from ghosts and take a picture of their body for profit
-Even when you get less scared of the horror aspect of the game, you still get scared at losing the $2k worth of items you just bought for the game!
Cons:
-Voice activation is still bugged and doesn't work for all accents
-Numerous bugs still in the game, some more severe than others
-No other thing to grind other than making money to buy items, could be cool if there was a way to grind for special skins or cosmetic things
-GUI is kinda crappy
-The dead do not play any part of the game from the grave, it may be fun to have ways to signal to the people still alive what they think the ghost is
- You will be mad when you die multiple games in a row while your friends laugh

Overall: 9/10

This game is an absolute blast! Quite a unique take on horror game play, or at least executed very well. You basically just have to gather clues, and determine what kind of ghost is haunting this location. Using various tools and tactics to bring the ghost out. There are many different kinds of ghosts, and it is never straight forward answer. So it provides a pretty good challenge every match and I haven’t even went up in difficulty yet. 
	The atmosphere is pure horror and I love it. The ambiance and sounds of the environment is top notch. Tension slowly builds up of the course of a game and will have you panicking by the end. Even in a party or if you play the same map over and over, it remains fresh.
	I only hope this doesn’t become a permanent early access. Hopefully we get the full release soon, and updates for years to come. That said, even in early access, it is still easily worth $13. The fact that it's this cheap, has no micro transactions and isn't a over the top grind fest, if refreshing to say the least. If ya want a new horror experience or to get scared with some friends, pick this one up!

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This is a half-indie game about ghost hunting... well, duh. Specifically it's all about investigating the ghost at hand and gather information about it. The reason every youtuber played it at some point, is that this game is constantly listening to your microphone and has voice recognition, which is essential for gameplay. You can interact with the ghost by calling it's name, asking them to do something like "Where are you?", "Give us a sign" etc. This is very interesting and fun, as this keeps you immersed, and the ghost doesn't necessarily do something if you ask it to. Cursing, saying you're scared, telling others to run/hide are some of the ways to increase the ghost's activity or anger it. The main objective is to find 3 pieces of evidence to find out what type of ghost you're dealing with (which there are over 12: spirit, poltergeist, demon, oni etc.). Each ghost type has unique behavior, level of aggression, strengths and weaknesses, which is an alternative way to determine what it is if you're having trouble getting evidence, as those might take a while (ex.: some ghosts take over 20 minutes to make the temperature go below 0 Celsius, thus letting you know that it has the "Freezing Temperatures" evidence). Problems getting the required evidence are presented as: the ghost trying to kill you in it's hunting phases, the ghost trying to scare you, the ghost messing with items nearby, the ghost messing with electricity etc. Although you get used to ways the game tries to scare you, every once in a while it gets me, and even people who played it for thousands of hours still get scared every once in a while. There are still many problems in this game, like: cursed player animation, players clipping through walls/doors/closets, numerous bugs, bad progression system (this one is being addressed by the developers), glitches involving voice chat/voice recognition etc. For me, personally, the game is just not fun playing it by yourself, you kind of take it seriously with 1 friend, and just plain old fun with 2 or more. I still recommend it, it's very good for enjoying sleepless nights with your friends.

Great game overall, a lot of fun to play by yourself or with friends. I currently have 200+ hrs in the game and am over level 500, so I've experienced pretty much all this game has to offer (including VR).

The game was scary the first few times I played but you get used to the scares and the different ghost behaviors. I will say the VR portion of the game is pretty well made and is pretty fun. If you're in for scares, play VR, it works on Oculus/Meta Quest 2 with the cable-computer connection as well. There have been many updates since I first started playing and the developers seem to keep busy both fixing and adding new items to the game. 

Overall one of my all time favorites and I highly recommend this game to anyone curious or on the fence about buying.

I'm a huge fan of shows such as Ghost Adventures, and at first this game was almost everything I wanted from this genre. However, after playing it a lot and waiting for updates that would expand the game mechanics and gameplay itself, those never really arrived.

Almost every other ghost hunting game out there has the exorcism mechanic built in, others even implemented amazing ideas such as the Ghost Exile's World of Shadows, Ghost's favourite ítem or the Labyrinth of death. Phasmophobia still is just a ghost identification game. Just as it was on release day. 

This game was the fírst of this genre, but it definitely wasn't able to keep up with what the community expected from it.

To be honest, after 90 something hours invested in this game playing with friends, I find it disappointing and just flat out repetitive. The whole premie doesn't even make sense: 

- Find out what ghost you are facing. 

+OK I will, what do I do once I find it out??

- You leave.

Honestly, I appreciate the amount of hours that it kept me and my friends entertained, but overall it's a huge missed oportunity. Even some games released after this one managed to implement more gameplay mechanics in less time, so it's fair to assume they just don't care about what's missing.

I uninstalled it recently and decided to give a chance to other phasmo-knockoffs, and honestly... I should have done it much sooner. I got that spooky feeling back and they feel like there will be much more content added in the future, which is much more than I can say for Phasmo after so long playing it. And more importantly, I finally do MORE than just identifying the ghost.

To sum up, check out Ghost Exile, add The Hauntings to tour wishlist (I'm so excited about this one, definitely check it out of you are into this kind of games) and check out Forewarned as well if you would like the same concept applied to mummies. Even Obsideo and Ghost Exorcists Corp managed to do most of it better than Phasmophobia. At least these ones listened to what their community was expecting from them and started applying those ideas into their games.

I hope one day I can rectify my review of this game, but so far it doesn't seem like the game will have any significant updates that will make me change my mind about this game.

This is a great horror game with friends that gets updates on the regular. Currently they are giving their assets some TLC. Some of my friends have said that this game shares assets with House Flipper. Maybe they got the same assets from an assets store? I wouldn't consider this a bad thing, just interesting.

The horror elements are on point! There is a build up of terror because you know the ghost is in the room but can't see it followed by the release of horror as the ghost suddenly appears to either spook you or hunt you.

Early on the game was very easy but they have ramped up the difficult by adjusting how detecting ghosts work. And then there's Nightmare difficulty...

Devs, custom levels would be excellent! Allowing the community to build custom levels for you would be fantastic and would increase the longevity of the game. Playing on the same 10 levels quickly leads to burn out.

This game really deserves even more recognition than it gets. 

You put 4 random people who DO NOT know each other into a server, and the only way to identify the ghost is to work together. 

That's it. The comedy and horror writes itself from there. Every game feels like a B-Movie ghost story with 4 actors who have no idea what they are doing, but have $5,000 in ghost hunting equipment sitting in an ice cream truck that you park outside of a location with one objective: Find the ghost. You get no clues where the ghost is. Is it cold? Maybe ghost? Guess what? It's snowing. Maybe try the spirit box? No reply. Why are the lights flickering? Oh, the ghost doesn't like voices and is now hell bent on killing your team 3 minutes into a hunt, which only just started because someone sneezed into the spirit box. Hunt over. One guy left. He has no mic. He panics. Door slams. Ghost moans. Mission failed. 

10/10, I would've gladly paid $60 for this game.
THIS GAME IS FUN AND INTERESTING

Horror games do not scare me. There are so many that fit under that umbrella, from Resident Evil to Amnesia, and most hit familiar beats: a few good jump scares, the dread of being pursued, nasty monsters and creepy sound effects. I enjoy all of these experiences, but even when things get intense I'm never really afraid.

Phasmophobia is a game that gets into your head. When you're playing the real world doesn't exist. When you stop, some aspect has seeped into reality. This game has left myself and companions not so much stunned as scrambled, jacked on adrenaline and chatting for hours afterwards about what just happened. 

The best summary of Phasmophobia would be a detective game about ghosts. You play as one of up to four investigators who go into various locations, from roadside houses to an asylum, and try to identify what kind of spirit it is being haunted by, and then leave. Though there's a serious Ghostbusters vibe here there's no actual busting: you're the pre-Ghostbusters, if you like, solely there to work out what kind of threat this is.

To this end you have various pieces of equipment, all simple in utility, stored in a van that acts as the team's command HQ at each location. There's a flashlight, which nearly always occupies one of your three inventory slots (VR players get four slots, which seems a tad unfair). The EMF reader is the PKE meter by another name, a little box that begins to light up in the presence of ghostly activity. A UV flashlight will show up ghostly fingerprints or footprints. A thermometer detects drops in room temperature.

All of this might make the game sound quite basic, like you just run into a house with an EMF reader, find a ghost, and that's job done. Well, try that the first time you play and good luck. Phasmophobia's genius is that this is a game of restraint and subtlety. Detecting the ghosts is always only a matter of time: the real beauty is that this is just the start.

The player character has limits. You can't move fast, you can only carry three items and so, even after working out where a ghost might be, you have to go back into the location multiple times with different equipment. Each type of ghost will (eventually) provide three types of evidence—for example, setting off the EMF at level 5 is one piece of evidence, freezing temperatures are another, and seeing ghost writing would be yet another.  

Here's where things start to get fascinating, terrifying, and even exhilarating. The game makes your initial hunts relatively gentle, then the ghosts move up a notch. They start to notice you faster. They'll start to mess with you. Maybe you temporarily lose track of the team, then hear an unmistakeable breath passing close by one ear. Maybe you even see a silhouette for a second. 

Phasmophobia's ghost will kill you but, more often than not, they will simply freak you and your team out. I've been coy because talking in-detail about a game like this risks ruining some of its best surprises, but I'll give one example.

It was a street house. The maps are three street houses, two farmouses, a school (huge), and an asylum (huge and confusing). This was one my team had handled before, and we quickly identified a child's bedroom upstairs as somewhere the ghost favoured.

I bravely hid in a cupboard. After a minute or two of radio silence, three of us regrouped but one was now dead in the hall. We went to the van, and went back to the child's bedroom with more gear. As we were setting up, the car alarm went off again. My companions went to turn it off, and I stayed to set up the last bits of gear.

I finished, turned and went towards the door, then saw my breath freeze in front of me. I heard my heartbeat, the lights started flashing, and a toddler's silhouette flashed by the corner of my eye. What exactly happened next I'll leave to your imagination, but once dead you can observe and listen-in to your former companions from a blue-lit realm where you can see the ghost but cannot help any further.

Key to Phasmophobia is the sound design: you have to run voice chat through the game itself, and then there's a local chat and a radio chat option. The difference matters because the ghosts can 'hear' you. In fact, some ghosts will speak to you, and even respond to an item called the Spirit Box that allows you to ask questions. 

But the 'hearing' element of the ghosts is so much more than it might seem, because what it seems to do is pick up on the moods of your team. It responds when people are scared and say hasty things like "let's just get out of here." I've seen people try to deliberately provoke it, and get absolutely nothing, then two minutes later when they're isolated for a split-second something shoots from the darkness and rips them apart. I cannot tell you what it's like to hide silently for minutes, then hear someone say "I think it's gone."

As all of this implies, Phasmophobia's greatness is in the human interactions that it's set up to provoke. It knows that no ghost is ever going to be as scary as the one in your head, and shows real restraint in how it uses small events and subtle clues to build an atmosphere that, at its best/worst, can be absolutely horrifying.

Phasmophobia is an early access game and reflects this: multiplayer works through lobbies, there's a levelling system but no real overarching structure, and it does need the new maps and ghost types which will surely arrive over time. 

But the beating heart of this experience is unlike anything else I've played. The experience depends on camaraderie and communication, as well as a decent smack of bravery, and the ghosts will mess with that combination in ways equally surprising and horrifying. Even when you're experienced, even when that first fear of the unknown has passed, Phasmophobia comes up with shit that'll turn you white.

Citizen Kane is a 1941 American drama film produced by, directed by, and starring Orson Welles. He also co-wrote the screenplay with Herman J. Mankiewicz. The picture was Welles' first feature film. Citizen Kane is widely regarded as the greatest film ever made.[5] For 50 consecutive years, it stood at number 1 in the British Film Institute's Sight & Sound decennial poll of critics, and it topped the American Film Institute's 100 Years ... 100 Movies list in 1998, as well as its 2007 update. The film was nominated for Academy Awards in nine categories and it won for Best Writing (Original Screenplay) by Mankiewicz and Welles. Citizen Kane is praised for Gregg Toland's cinematography, Robert Wise's editing, Bernard Herrmann's music, and its narrative structure, all of which have been considered innovative and precedent-setting.

The quasi-biographical film examines the life and legacy of Charles Foster Kane, played by Welles, a composite character based on American media barons William Randolph Hearst and Joseph Pulitzer, Chicago tycoons Samuel Insull and Harold McCormick, as well as aspects of the screenwriters' own lives. Upon its release, Hearst prohibited the film from being mentioned in his newspapers.[6]

After the Broadway success of Welles's Mercury Theatre and the controversial 1938 radio broadcast "The War of the Worlds" on The Mercury Theatre on the Air, Welles was courted by Hollywood. He signed a contract with RKO Pictures in 1939. Although it was unusual for an untried director, he was given freedom to develop his own story, to use his own cast and crew, and to have final cut privilege. Following two abortive attempts to get a project off the ground, he wrote the screenplay for Citizen Kane, collaborating with Herman J. Mankiewicz. Principal photography took place in 1940, the same year its innovative trailer was shown, and the film was released in 1941.

Although it was a critical success, Citizen Kane failed to recoup its costs at the box office. The film faded from view after its release, but it returned to public attention when it was praised by French critics such as André Bazin and re-released in 1956. In 1958, the film was voted number 9 on the prestigious Brussels 12 list at the 1958 World Expo. Citizen Kane was selected by the Library of Congress as an inductee of the 1989 inaugural group of 25 films for preservation in the United States National Film Registry for being "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant".[7][8][9]
